item.description:
Halibut Pt. state Park Sea Rocks have moderate walking trails( make sure you wear comfy shoes etc) , scenic views, amazig tidal pools and rocky ledges perfect for a picnic.. MODERATE HIKING. So, we will be having a POT LUCK PICNIC! Don't forget to bring your camera for this! Check our photos from the last visit!
If there is enough interest, I will phone the friendly park Ranger. The last time we visited he was great , allowing members to go inside the WW2 tower commanding spectacular views. He later did a short presentation.

COST: There may be a parking fee
TIME : 11am
POT LUCK PICNIC: tentative time is- 12:30/1pm in the park

PL PICNIC NOTE: We are having a Pot Luck Picnic in the park! These are so much fun! If you would like to participate? Please bring a food item to share and your own water/beverage.I will supply the plastic, napkins, plates and trash bags ( plus food time(s)) As far as I know there are no grills., but I will find out. Since this is "pot luck" think of it as an adventure ...there is no list. Tentative time is - 12:30 /1pm.


* Later on, we can go into downtown Rockport to stroll along Bearskin Neck among it's galeries and unique shops. PARKING IS TIGHT. At this type of venue members usually break off into smaller groups. If this is a problem for anyone, it may not be the best event for you to attend. There are a few interesting cafes, restaurants & take out places for ice cream and food. I have invited 3 other meetup groups for this event.

****Rain or Intense heat will cancel this event. Please make sure to check for updates before heading out.


HALIBUT PT.
is a uniquely beautiful coastal seascape. Looking seaward on a clear day, the view stretches from Crane Beach in Ipswich to Mount Agamenticus in Maine and the Isles of Shoals off the coast of New Hampshire.
Formerly the Babson Farm granite quarry, the park is managed for scenic, historic and conservation purposes by the DCR and the Trustees of Reservations. An adjacent property, Sea Rocks, is owned by the Town of Rockport and open for public use. Here you can explore the park's trails and tidepools, picnic on its rocky ledges, enjoy its sweeping views, and learn about Cape Ann's historic granite industry.
VISITORS CENTER:
Located in a renovated World War II fire-control tower near the edge of the Babson Farm quarry, the center features exhibits related to the park's natural and cultural history. The 60-foot tall structure offers panoramic views that extend as far north as the coast of Maine. The building also serves as the park's administrative headquarters.
HISTORY:
Halibut Point itself is made of sheets of 440 million year-old granite that now descend from rocky headland to the tidal pools below. As a result of the shallow soil, constant exposure to onshore winds, and a history of frequent fires, the vegetation includes few trees. Catbriar, bayberry, blueberry, arrowwood, shadbush, and an assortment of wildflowers grow among the ledges. Each winter, many species of seabirds, including loons, grebes, ducks and an occasional puffin, feed in the rich offshore waters.
Beginning in the 1840s, granite was quarried from this area, first on a small scale and primarily along the coast, and then on a much larger scale when the Rockport Granite Company acquired the Babson Farm quarry and expanded its operation. Shortly after the Cape Ann granite industry collapsed in 1929, 17 acres on the eastern side of the quarry were purchased and given to the Trustees of Reservations. The remainder of the area sat unused until late in World War II when a fire control tower (now the park's Visitors Center) was constructed to provide aiming information for the massive coastal defense guns that guarded Boston and Portsmouth Harbors.
item.how_to_find_us: meetup INSIDE the park, outside the visitor's center. I will have a meetup sign
item.name: Sweeping Views, Gorgeous Vistas, Stroll Thru an Old NE Treasure & PL Picnic
